Thanks for the fast merge, @saguziel !

I believe this should be in the default config template to work when not specified. 

Curiously, are you running an older version of Airflow? The visibility timeout issue should not cause any (real) issues in the 1.8+

Oh I'll check and add it to the default config too/instead then.

I'm running 1.8.1, and it causes a reproducible issue on backfill tasks that take longer than 1 hour. (But not on normal tasks runs) I believe it also causes an issue on SubDags but this is not personal experience.

The other thing this helps with is using SQS in a non-default region (i.e. I was unable to get SQS working without a hack in eu-west-1 so switched to redis instead)

Ah yes, you were correct. I did not realise that the default config was loaded first and then the user's config merged in on top.

I also decided to add a small test to cover this config object.
I'm very much looking forward to see this change merged. It's causing some real issues in our workflows, preventing us from using SubDags at all and having to do several workarounds ðŸ‘
@mrkm4ntr, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @bolkedebruin, @mistercrunch and @AllisonWang to be potential reviewers.

Sigh. timing based tests on distributed/public infrastrucutre :(

> ```
> 11) FAIL: test_scheduler_run_duration (tests.SchedulerJobTest)
> 
> ----------------------------------------------------------------------
>

> ```
LGTM
+1 LGTM
I merged this, but Apache isn't closing it.
Thanks for merging!

@artwr @criccomini (+ @saguziel @bolkedebruin) seems like you guys reviewed similar AWS related PR - https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1630

Would be great if you could help review my PR. Any inputs are welcome (this is my first contribution to airflow) :)

@bolkedebruin thanks will add tests.

Thanks @bolkedebruin, yes celery 3 should still supported because the existing celery 3 style config setting names are kept intact. Also, loading via module name was supported celery 3.1 [method config_from_object called on config_source](http://docs.celeryproject.org/en/3.1/reference/celery.html#celery.Celery.config_from_object) 

Celery 4 is backwards compatible with celery 3 config names so upgrade to celery 4 will not be an issue either:
http://docs.celeryproject.org/en/latest/whatsnew-4.0.html#step-2-update-your-configuration-with-the-new-setting-names

However, if users want to use newer celery 4 style configs they probably should update all of the celery config, otherwise mixing old and new styles can throw an error: https://github.com/celery/celery/blob/master/celery/app/utils.py#L247
Thanks for your answer, but it is not the answer to what I meant. I meant is celery 3 still supported by celery? They are at 4.1 now which is two major releases beyond 3.

Once we have that set, if you guys could test it out and report back any bugs/feature requests that would be super helpful :)

Sorry I dont have the answer to that. ill have to defer to the celery devs. At a minimum all I can tell is that they will be supporting celery 3 style configurations in celery 4.

I'm not sure if I'm in the position to force everyone to use celery 4. If this PR is to be included in a minor release, I didn't want to break people's cfgs of users who didn't update so i kept these changes as minimal as possible but still give a ton of flexibility to airflow users (which includes updating to celery 4).

Would it be safer to include that in a separate PR to do more extensive testing with celery 4? that way the new config names can be properly tested and updated throughout the codebase as well.
